data.text: A sturdy bag designed for carrying articles on a person's back, having shoulder straps and often mounted on a lightweight frame.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A piece of equipment, often containing life-support devices, designed to be used while being carried on the back.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: a parachute in a backpack; an astronaut's backpack.

data.text: To hike or travel while carrying a backpack.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: a bag carried on the back, supported by straps looped over the shoulders.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: to hike while carrying a backpack; -- often used in the form <altname>go backpacking</altname>.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: A <xref>knapsack</xref>, sometimes <xref>mounted</xref> on a light <xref>frame</xref>, but always supported by <xref>straps</xref>, worn on a person’s back for the purpose of <xref>carrying</xref> things, especially when <xref>hiking</xref>, or on a student's back when <xref>carrying</xref> books.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: A similarly placed item containing a <xref>parachute</xref> or other <xref>life-support</xref> <xref>equipment</xref>.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: To hike and camp overnight in backcountry with one's gear carried in a backpack.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: To engage in low-cost, generally urban, travel with minimal luggage and frugal accommodations.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.
